Description: Body sherd of South Ionian pottery cup, probably a cup with everted rim; interior mostly reserved with two black bands; exterior: handle zone reserved, black below; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2
Curator's comments: Schlotzhauer identifies this sherd as possibly coming from a Type 9 South Ionian cup with everted rim. The lack of a rim prevents any more precise identification but the banded decoration on the interior might suggest that the sherd belongs to the Type 9B. Type 9B cups closely follow the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape.
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 54, no. 19)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.635) (Phase 3)
